image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Illinois; born in Chicago, Cook County, Ill., February 8, 1927; graduated from Immaculate Conception High School, Elmhurst, Ill., 1944; attended Notre Dame, Notre Dame, Ind., 1944; attended the University of Illinois, 1945-1946; attended Loyola University, Chicago, Ill.; J.D., Loyola University Law School, Chicago, Ill., 1949; United States Navy, 1944-1946; lawyer, private practice; assistant State's attorney, Du Page County, Ill., 1950-1952; member of the Illinois state house of representatives, 1957-1965; elected as a Republican to the Eighty-ninth and to the nine succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1965-January 3, 1985); not a candidate for reelection to the Ninety-ninth Congress in 1984; adjunct faculty, Georgetown University Law Center, Washington, D.C.; board member, Legal Services Corporation, 1989-2001; interim president, Legal Services Corporation, 2001-2003; died on October 30, 2005, in Warrenton, Ill.; interment at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, Va.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Erlenborn, John Neal. "The Abuses of the Majority: How the Democrats and Labor Chieftains Run the Congress." In Can You Afford This House? Edited by David Treen, 33-38. Ottawa, IL: Green Hill Books, 1978.
Ralph Nader Congress Project. Citizens Look at Congress: John N. Erlenborn, Republican Representative from Illinois. Washington, D. C.: Grossman Publishers, 1972.

researchRecord.name: 1967-1968, 7.25 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The John N. Erlenborn Papers contain constituent correspondence from DuPage and Will Counties concerning foreign policy and business and labor legislation. A finding aid is available in the repository. Restricted.

researchRecord.name: 1965-1984, 145 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The John N. Erlenborn Collection consists of correspondence with constituents, transcripts of speeches, documentation of all committee work (particularly the Committee on Government Operations and the Committee on Education and Labor), bills introduced by Erlenborn, photographs, scrapbooks, and other ephemera. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.
